sentences: Peter Andrew Saville  (born 9 October 1955) is an English art director and graphic designer.
He came to prominence for the many record sleeves he designed for Factory Records, which he co-founded in 1978 alongside Tony Wilson and Alan Erasmus.
He studied graphic design at Manchester Polytechnic from 1975 to 1978.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Influenced by fellow student Malcolm Garrett, who had begun designing for the Manchester punk group, Buzzcocks and by Herbert Spencer's Pioneers of Modern Typography, Saville was inspired by Jan Tschichold, chief propagandist for the New Typography.
section: == Factory Records ==

sentences: Kelly and Saville won a Designers and Art Directors Award for the sleeve of Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark's 1980 self-titled first album.
section: == Factory Records ==

sentences: Saville's album design for Joy Division's last album, Closer, released shortly after Ian Curtis' suicide in May 1980, was controversial in its depiction of Christ's body entombed.
section: == Factory Records ==

sentences: However, the design pre-dated Curtis's death, which the magazine New Musical Express confirmed, since it had been displaying proofs of the artwork in its offices for several months.
section: == Factory Records ==

section: == Factory Records ==

sentences: A Fantin-Latour "Roses" painting in combination with a colour-coded alphabet became the seminal album cover for New Order's Power, Corruption & Lies (1983), for example.
section: == Factory Records ==

sentences: "In the 2002 film 24 Hour Party People, which is based on Tony Wilson and the history of Factory Records, Saville is portrayed by actor Enzo Cilenti.
section: == Factory Records ==

section: == Factory Records ==

sentences: In 1979, Saville moved from Manchester to London and became art director of the Virgin offshoot Dindisc.
section: == Non-Factory work ==

sentences: He was paid more to design Gabriel's 1986 album So than for any other record sleeve in his career; he received £20,000.
section: == Non-Factory work ==

sentences: Saville founded the design agency Peter Saville Associates (still designing primarily for musical artists and record labels), which included Brett Wickens, before he was invited to close his office in 1990 to join the partner-owned Pentagram.
section: == Non-Factory work ==

sentences: Saville collaborated with Transport for Greater Manchester in 2008 for the rebranding of the Metrolink tram system with a yellow and silver polka-dot scheme after a period of significant expansion had been undertaken on the network.
section: == Non-Factory work ==

sentences: In 1993 Saville left London and moved to Los Angeles, to join ad agency Frankfurt Balkind with Brett Wickens.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: In 1993 Saville left London and moved to Los Angeles, to join ad agency Frankfurt Balkind with Brett Wickens.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: For three years they worked from "The Apartment" in partnership with German advertising agency Meiré & Meiré.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: In 1999 Saville moved to offices in Clerkenwell.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: The two launched the art and fashion website SHOWstudio in November 2000.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: Belgian fashion designer Raf Simons was granted full access to the archives of Saville's vintage Factory projects and made a personal selection of Saville-designed works to integrate them into Raf Simons "Closer" Autumn/Winter 2003-04 collection.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: Raf Simons Spring/Summer 2018 collection also features a selection of archival works by Saville.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: In 2004 Saville became Creative Director of the City of Manchester, playing a strategic role in the regeneration and cultural renaissance of his home city, notably defining the ethos for the Manchester International Festival.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: In 2010 Saville designed the England football team home shirt.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: Saville has three D&AD awards, is a Royal Designer for Industry and won the London Design Medal in 2013.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: Saville has three D&AD awards, is a Royal Designer for Industry and won the London Design Medal in 2013.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: In 2012 Saville collaborated with Dovecot Studios, Edinburgh in celebration of their centenary to create a large scale tapestry of his work After, After Monarch of the Glen.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: This new tapestry commission is Dovecot Studios re appropriation of Peter Saville's appropriation of Sir Peter Blake's appropriation of Sir Edwin Landseer's 1851 painting Monarch of the Glen.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: In 2018, Saville redesigned the logo for British luxury fashion house Burberry, as revealed by then creative director Riccardo Tisci.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: In July 2019 Saville was featured in the BBC Radio 4 programme Only Artists in conversation with industrial designer Marek Reichman.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: Saville was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 2020 New Year Honours for services to design.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: Saville was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 2020 New Year Honours for services to design.
section: == Work after Factory Records ==

sentences: Saville's reclaimed status and contribution to graphic design were firmly established when London's Design Museum exhibited his body of work in 2003.
section: == Exhibition, book and soundtrack ==

sentences: The exhibition, The Peter Saville Show, was open from 23 May through 14 September 2003.
section: == Exhibition, book and soundtrack ==

section: == Exhibition, book and soundtrack ==

sentences: Anna Blessmann and Peter Saville met in a gallery in Berlin in 2001 and soon began an artwork collaboration, works have been shown at Paul Stolper Gallery London, CRAC Alsace, Migros Museum Zurich, Whitechapel London and in various publications.
section: == Swing Project ==

sentences: In 2010 they presented 'Swing Project 1' in the FRAC Champagne-Ardenne, Reims and in 2012 'Swing Project 2' at Galerie Neu, Berlin.
section: == Swing Project ==
